stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Spear-Phishing Campaign Using ���The PLA's New Organizational Structure��� and ���NIDS China Security Report 2016 forwarded��� Themed Emails Containing Suspected Malicious Links
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description: US-CERT was notified by trusted third party of a spear phishing campaign using ���The PLA's New Organizational Structure: What is Known, Unknown and Speculation, Parts��� and ���NIDS China Security Report 2016 forwarded��� themed emails containing suspected malicious links.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious E-mail Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The sender's email address was spoofed.
Spacing errors are as noted in email body below.
-----BEGIN EMAIL BODY-----
The PLA's New Organizational Structure
(What is Known, Unknown and Speculation, Parts 1 & 2)
On December 31, 2015, the China's People's Liberation Army (PLA) began its eleventh major reorganization since 1952. Most previous reorganizations focused on reducing the size of the infantry and bloated higher-echelon headquarters, turning over entire organizations, such as the railway corps, to civilian control, and transferring units to the Ministry of Public Security (MPS) and the People's Armed Police (PAP).
To date, most Western analysis of the current reorganization has addressed the reasons for and policy implications of the current reorganization. Instead,thisreportaddresseswhatisknownaboutchangestothePLA'sorganizationalstructure the essential factor needed to inform any credible analysis of the reasons for and the implications of the current reorganization.
The report tries and finds answers to the Unanswered Questions like
Will the CMC departments/commissions/offices and theater headquarters become true "joint" organizations with a balanced mix among members from each of the four services plus the PLASSF?
Has the role of MND been changed?
How will the remaining 2 million personnel be balanced among the services?
How will the PLA's 2 million personnel be divided among officers, uniformed civil cadre, noncommissioned officers (NCOs), and conscripts/volunteers?
Will the local headquarters system of provincial Military Districts, Military Sub-districts, and Peoples Armed Force Departments be altered?
What operational units will be disbanded?
Will there be any change to the organization and subordination of the PLAN's three fleets?
To what headquarters (or CMC) is the PLASSF subordinate? What units comprise the PLASSF? What are the specific missions of the PLASSF?
In addition to reductions in the militia, will PLA reserve units undergo change?
What is the status of the Academy of Military Science, National Defense University, and National University of Defense Technology?
Will there be any changes to the CMC and State Council/Ministry of Public Security's dual command of the People's Armed Police?
Download to Read the complete comprehensive report (http://t.ymlp50.com/jbualaejswyacajhwapawbhmj/click.php) Hidden link to http://www.cnmilit.com/index.php?f=The_PLA_s_New_Organizational_Structure_Parts_1_and_2_01.doc
Unsubscribe / Change Profile
Powered by YMLP
-----END EMAIL BODY-----

EmailMessageObj:Header.EmailMessageObj:Subject: The PLA's New Organizational Structure: What is Known, Unknown and Speculation, Parts

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious E-mail Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
The sender's email address was spoofed.
-----BEGIN EMAIL BODY----- NIDS China Security Report 2016(Mar 2016 Report) (The Expanding Scope of PLA Activities and the PLA Strategy)
The NIDS China Security Report published by the National Institute for Defense Studies (NIDS) is widely distributed in Japan and abroad to provide analysis conducted by NIDS researchers on China's military affairs and security from a mid- to long-term perspec- tive.
The current NIDS China Security Report 2016 is the sixth annual edition, "The Expanding Scope of PLA Activities and the PLA Strategy," it examines the major influence the People's Liberation Army (PLA) exerts on security in the region through the PLA Navy (PLAN), Air Force (PLAAF), and Second Artillery Force (PLASAF; reorganized into the PLA Rocket Force at the end of December 2015).
Each of these services has its own basic strategy, and the Report analyzes the overall trend toward greater military strength accompanying efforts to put those strategies fully into effect. It also analyzes the implications for security in East Asia represented by the PLA's current situation as well as the trend toward the joint operation of these various services.
The report has been covered as under:- - Introduction - Strengthening Operational Capabilities in Open Seas -The PLAN
China's Changing Naval Strategy Increasingly Active Naval Operations over a Wider Area Future Development of the PLAN
- Revising Its Strategic Posture and Expanding Capabilities -The PLAAF
PLAAF Strategy: From Territorial Air Defense to Integrated Aerospace Capabilities and Simultaneous Offense and Defense Modernization of Air Force Equipment Looking to the Chinese Air Force of the Future The Gaoxin Project
- Expanding and Strengthening Its Missile Force -The PLASAF Nuclear Force Aiming at Assured Second-Strike Capacity Development of Conventional Missiles The Future of the PLASAF Development of Hypersonic Glide Vehicles
- Enhancement of the PLA's Joint Operational Capabilities
Aiming to Win Informationized Local Wars Enhancing Capabilities for System-versus-System Operations The Direction of Reforms of Command and Force Structures
Download to Read the complete 80 page comprehensive report (http://t.ymlp50.com/jbsanaejswyagajjbapawbwjm/click.php)
Unsubscribe / Change Profile Powered by YMLP
-----END EMAIL BODY-----
